title: Comparative Philosophy of Mind: From Avicenna to Vasubandhu
description: Cross-cultural philosophy of mind, consciousness, and intellect: Islamic Peripatetic psychology (Avicenna, Averroes), Scholastic synthesis (Aquinas), Cambridge Platonism (More, Smith), Jewish Neoplatonism (Ibn Gabirol), Neo-Confucianism (Zhu Xi), and Buddhist Abhidharma (Nagarjuna, Vasubandhu).

books.title: Long Commentary on the De Anima
books.author: Averroes (Ibn Rushd)

books.title: Commentary on Treatise on the Soul
books.author: Thomas Aquinas

keyTheories: Avicenna: Active Intellect, flying man thought experiment, soul's immortality
Averroes: Universal Intellect shared by all humanity, sparked medieval controversies
Aquinas: Soul as substantial form of body, subsists after death
Cambridge Platonists: Immaterial spiritual substance, deiformity of soul
Ibn Gabirol: Universal hylomorphism - matter and form in all creatures including angels
Zhu Xi: Principle (li) and material force (qi), mind of the Way vs human mind
Nagarjuna: Emptiness of consciousness, no inherent existence
Vasubandhu: Abhidharma psychology, analysis of mental factors and consciousness
researchValue: Enables unprecedented comparative study of theories of mind across Islamic, Christian, Jewish, Chinese, and Buddhist traditions. Documents transmission of Greek philosophy through Arabic to Latin Europe. Essential for understanding pre-modern philosophy of consciousness.
